name: Get Servers
info: Simply run the `jupyter server list` command and parse the output as an array of objects containing server properties.

meta.author: Paulo Felipe Jarschel <pfjarsschel@gmail.com>
meta.desc: Get a list of running Jupyter servers

name: Jupyter Manager

meta.author: Paulo Felipe Jarschel <pfjarschel@gmail.com>
meta.desc: Manage Jupyter servers available to the flow

name: Execute Python Code
info:
Takes a text input and attempt to run it at a Jupyter server.
Multiline supported.
Entire thousands-of-lines codes are supported.

The use of a template node as input is recommended, but anything goes.

Python output is passed on as the msg.payload and logged (cropped) to the console.

meta.author: Paulo Felipe Jarschel <pfjarschel@gmail.com>
meta.desc: Execute python code on a running Jupyter server

name: Get Data from Python
info:
Get data from a variable that exists in the Jupyter kernel.

The input payload is the variable name, or an array with the variable names (as strings).
If the requested variable(s) is(are) not defined, an empty string will be returned instead.
Also, if the requested variable is actually a non-serializable object, an empty string will be returned as well.

Currently, it returns a JSON containing the variables names and data as key/value pairs.
So far, this approach seems the most effective, as it can handle strings, numbers, arrays and etc. with ease.

Lists, tuples, dicts, numpy arrays and pandas dataframes are supported (nested or not).

meta.author: Paulo Felipe Jarschel <pfjarschel@gmail.com>
meta.desc: Get data from a variable that exists in the Jupyter kernel

print('running')

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
print('import ok')

n = 1000
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, n)
y = np.sin(x) + 0.4*(np.random.random(n) - 0.5)
print('vars ok')

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.savefig('foo.png', dpi=300)
print('plot done')
